column1: ~ 00:00|"around midnight"|"Charlotte tore quite a section out of her web
column2: leaving an open space in the middle. Then she started weaving something to take the place of the threads she had removed. When Templeton got back from the dump
column4: the spider was still at work."|"Charlotte's Web"|"E. B. White"

column1: ap 08:30|eight-thirty|"Lurvy was in bed by eight-thirty. He lay dreaming that he was throwing baseballs at a cloth cat and winning a genuine Navajo blanket. Mr. and Mrs. Zuckerman were in bed by nine. Mrs. Zuckerman lay dreaming about a deep freeze unit. Mr. Zuckerman lay dreaming about Wilbur. He dreamt that Wilbur had grown until he was one hundred and sixteen feet long and ninety-two feet high and that he had won all the prizes at the Fair and was covered with blue ribbons and even had a blue ribbon tied to the end of his tail."|"Charlotte's Web"|"E. B. White"
12:00|noontime|"“Let’s let the children go off by themselves
column2: ” suggested Mr. Arable. “The Fair only comes once a year.” Mr. Arable gave Fern two quarters and two dimes. He gave Avery five dimes and four nickels. “Now run along!” he said. “And remember
column3: the money has to last all day. Don’t spend it all the first few minutes. And be back here at the truck at noontime so we can all have lunch together. And don’t eat a lot of stuff that’s going to make you sick to your stomachs.”"|"Charlotte's Web"|"E. B. White"

column1: 12:00|noon|"All morning Templeton slept quietly under the straw. The day grew fiercely hot. At noon the Zuckermans and the Arables returned to the pigpen. Then
column3: Fern and Avery showed up. Fern had a monkey doll in her arms and was eating Crackerjack. Avery had a balloon tied to his ear and was chewing a candied apple. The children were hot and dirty."|"Charlotte's Web"|"E. B. White"

column2: Mr. Arable’s truck rolled into the Fair Grounds and came to a stop at Wilbur’s pen. Everybody climbed out."|"Charlotte's Web"|"E. B. White"

column1: ap ~ 04:00|"about four o’clock"|"Wilbur heard the words of praise. He felt the warm milk inside his stomach. He felt the pleasant rubbing of the stick along his itchy back. He felt peaceful and happy and sleepy. This had been a tiring afternoon. It was still only about four o’clock but Wilbur was ready for bed."|"Charlotte's Web"|"E. B. White"

column1: ap 06:00|six|"Wilbur had gone to sleep thinking about these plans. He awoke at six and saw the rain
column2: and it seemed as though he couldn’t bear it."|"Charlotte's Web"|"E. B. White"

column1: ap 06:30|six-thirty|"At six-thirty Wilbur heard the banging of a pail. Lurvy was standing outside in the rain
column2: stirring up breakfast."|"Charlotte's Web"|"E. B. White"

column1: 00:00|midnight|"A dozen times during the night Wilbur woke and stared into the blackness
column2: listening to the sounds and trying to figure out what time it was. A barn is never perfectly quiet. Even at midnight there is usually something stirring."|"Charlotte's Web"|"E. B. White"
